dismiss.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to refuse to consider someone’s idea, opinion etc, because you think it is not serious, true, or important
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The government has dismissed criticisms that the country’s health policy is a mess.
It’s an idea that shouldn’t be dismissed out of hand  (=dismissed immediately and completely).
He just laughed and dismissed my proposal as unrealistic.
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to remove someone from their job
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Bryant was unfairly dismissed from his post.
Employees can be dismissed for sending obscene emails.
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[1].no: In everyday British English, people usually say sack someone, and in everyday American English, people usually say fire someone, rather than use dismiss:
He was sacked  (British English)/fired (American English) for being late all the time.
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to tell someone that they are allowed to go, or are no longer needed
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: The class was dismissed early today.
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if a judge dismisses a court case, he or she stops it from continuing
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: The case was dismissed owing to lack of evidence.
dismiss.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to end the innings of a player or team in the game of cricket
dismiss.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: dismiss an idea/suggestion
Both actors dismissed any idea of a romantic relationship between them.
dismiss a notion
The Minister dismissed the notion that he had cut petrol tax because of the forthcoming by-election.
dismiss a possibility
The prime minister dismissed the possibility of an early election.
dismiss a claim
An industrial tribunal dismissed his claim of unfair discrimination.
dismiss an allegation/charge
She claimed that she was honest and dismissed the allegations against her.
dismiss a thought
Was he lying? I tried to dismiss the thought.
dismiss fears
The Transport Minister dismissed fears that the Cotswold railway line would close.
dismiss criticism
He dismissed criticism of the country's human rights record.
easily/lightly
This is a question that cannot be dismissed lightly.
dismiss something out of hand
It's an interesting idea so don't dismiss it out of hand.
dismiss.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to remove someone from their job, usually because they have done something wrong
dismiss.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: He was dismissed from his job at a bank for repeatedly turning up to work late.
dismiss.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to state officially that a court case cannot continue because there is not enough evidence against the accused person
dismiss.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The prosecution offered no evidence and the case was dismissed.
